narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel far more confident in my understanding of the history and inner-workings of the EU.
Learned a lot about the history of the EU (and before), the major debates and issues in the EU, and even about very recent events.
A more nuanced understanding of the EU, its history and the challenges it faces today.
You learn about the inner workings and dynamic politics of the European Union. You also learn how to write and speak about the topic with nuance and authority.
knowledge of how the EU functions technically, problems its faced, popular politics across the EU, skills include writing a research prospectus

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Material interesting. Professor was very knowledgeable, but did not call on certain students who never volunteered to contribute. As a result there was an uneven contribution by students, as some very engaged and others were clearly not.

One strength is the structure - every week is a reading about an aspect of the EU or a current issue, which builds a pretty thorough understanding of the EU by the time the course ends. Professor Cameron is also very kind and helpful, and took challenges associated with COVID into consideration. The only weakness I can think of is that the style of discussion is the same every week, and you might find it challenging if you are a visual person.

Strengths: Topic, Reading Material, Professor's Experience 
Weaknesses: Difficult to get feedback

strengths: professor cameron's kindness and encyclopedic knowledge, his organization of the course
weaknesses: perhaps a bit too wonky at times esp on weeks about the EU's organization

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor calling on students when they raised there hand facilitated discussion.
Professor Cameron adapted one of the main assignments of the course to be more manageable during COVID, which was very much appreciated!
all were great, reading responses forced high engagement from all

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I definitely would. Professor Cameron really let's you go into the areas of the EU that interest you most (for me, that was issues of membership, policy creation an enforcement), so there is lots of flexibility within the structure of the course.

Students who are either already interested or passionate to learn about the EU and European history of the past 70 years should take the course. Otherwise, I would say not, given that material can sometimes be quite niche and technical.

Yes! If you are remotely interested in the EU, take it. The readings are well-chosen, the course is well-structured and Professor Cameron is very kind and helpful. Some background knowledge is useful but definitely not required, so don't be afraid to take it if you know nothing about the EU. The workload is manageable, but if you're taking this then I'd recommend balancing it out with classes that don't require as much reading.

yes def, u will gain basic knowledge of EU structure and politics from an absolute gem of a professor. relatively light long term work but weekly reading responses force u to engage deeply and come prepared to discuss the readings. also made for a more enjoyable seminar bc everyone had something to say

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
